verses.verse: ((When David was rebuked by the Prophet Nathan for his great offenses, he did not only acknowledge the same to God, with protestation of his natural corruption and iniquity, but also left a memorial thereof to his posterity.7 Therefore first he desireth God to forgive his sins,10 And to renew in him his holy Spirit.13 With promise that he will not be unmindful of those great graces.18 Finally, fearing lest God would punish the whole Church for his fault, he requireth that he would rather increase his graces toward the same.) Have mercy upon me, O God, (As his sins were manifold and great, so he requireth that God would give him the feeling of his excellent and abundant mercies.) according to thy loving-kindness: according to the multitude of thy compassions put away mine iniquities.
Wash me (My sins strike so fast in me, that I have need of some singular kind of washing.) thoroughly from mine iniquity, and cleanse me from mine sin.
For I (My conscience accuseth me so, that I can have no rest till I be reconciled.) know mine iniquities, and my sin is ever before me.

Against thee, against thee only have I sinned, and done evil in thy sight, that thou mayest be just when thou (When thou givest sentence against sinners, they must needs confess thee to be just, and themselves sinners.) speakest, and pure when thou judgest.
Behold, I was born in iniquity, and in sin hath my mother conceived me.

Behold, thou (He confesseth that God who loveth pureness of heart, may justly destroy man, who of nature is a sinner much more him, whom he had instructed in his heavenly wisdom.) lovest truth in the inward affections: therefore hast thou taught me wisdom in the secret of mine heart.
Purge me with (Cross references: : Lev. 14:6) hyssop, and I shall be clean: wash me, and I shall be whiter than snow.

Make me to hear (He meaneth God’s comfortable mercies toward repentant sinners.) joy and gladness, that the (By the bones he understandeth all strength of soul and body, which by cares and mourning are consumed.) bones, which thou hast broken, may rejoice.
Hide thy face from my sins, and put away all mine iniquities.
(He confesseth that when God’s Spirit is cold in us, to have it again revived, is as a new creation.) Create in me a clean heart, O God, and renew a right spirit within me.
Cast me not away from thy presence, and take not thine holy Spirit from me.
Restore to me the joy of thy salvation, and establish me with thy (Which may assure me that I am drawn out of the slavery of sin.) free Spirit.
Then shall I teach thy (He promiseth to endeavor that others by his example may turn to God.) ways unto the wicked, and sinners shall be converted unto thee.

Deliver me from (From the murder of Uriah, and the others that were slain with him, 2 Sam. 11:17.) blood, O God, which art the God of my salvation, and my tongue shall sing joyfully of thy righteousness.
(By giving me occasion to praise thee, when thou shalt forgive my sins.) Open thou my lips, O Lord, and my mouth shall show forth thy praise.
For thou desirest no sacrifice, though I would give it: thou delightest not in burnt offering.
The sacrifices of God are a (Which is a wounding of the heart, proceeding of faith, which seeketh unto God for mercy.) contrite spirit: a contrite and a broken heart, O God, thou wilt not despise.
Be favorable unto (He prayeth for the whole Church, because through his sin it was in danger of God’s judgment.) Zion for thy good pleasure: build the walls of Jerusalem.

Then shalt thou accept the sacrifices of (That is, just and lawful, applied to the right end, which is the exercise of faith and repentance.) righteousness, even the burnt offering and oblation: then shall they offer calves upon thine altar.
